title: Hypoglycemia
text: Hypoglycemia strongly independently associated increased mortality critically ill [1–6]. also causes major physiological stress , severe, neuronal injury [6–9]. sedated, critically ill patients, hypoglycemia typically clinically silent can detected blood glucose measurement. measurements often occur two four hourly intervals, depending level patient care, even less frequently [10], therefore creating substantial risk unrecognized hypoglycemia. Consequently, ability predict hypoglycemia hours occurs allow clinicians implement preventive measures, increase patient safety, perhaps improve clinical outcomes. advent availability large scale electronic health record (EHR) data, problem can investigated examining interplay key variables relate glycemic control. Known relevant factors affect glycemia might indicative future hypoglycemic episodes, also routinely collected available EHRs, include, degree metabolic stress (estimated lactate levels), degree hemodynamic stress (represented mean arterial pressure vasopressor therapy), degree hepatic physiological reserve (available liver function tests), severity critical illness using example sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) score [11], administration insulin, well preceding current blood glucose concentrations. Lactate levels may particularly important central role lactate key metabolic intermediary [12, 13] major hepatic gluconeogenic precursor [12, 14, 15]. Recently, randomized controlled trials attempted control blood glucose level according average blood glucose level prior ICU admission (measured HbA1c). RCT, [16] confirmed dangers hypoglycemia, hypothesized reason individualized intervention control glucose failed [17]. Similar studies future might performed conjunction AI-based alarm system hypoglycemia, emphasizing practical importance discussed prediction problem.

title: Hypoglycemia
text: Patients enter intensive care unit (ICU) monitored blood glucose levels. commonly used target range blood glucose critiically ill patients 108 mg/dL 180 mg/dL. However, instances glucose levels drop \(70\) mg/dL considered dangerous, interest prevent . graphical representation hypoglycemic event might occur ICU. following parameters especially relevant prediction problem: \[\begin{align*}   L &= \text{early prior onset prediction valid} \\   R &= \text{much advance prediction valid} \\ \end{align*}\] consider choices \(L = 12\) hours \(R = 1\) hours appropriate. Furthermore, designing alarm system, prevent alarm fatigue, alarms ring frequently, consider using alarm silencing, defined parameter: \[\begin{align*}     \delta = \text{duration alarm silencing alarm raised} \end{align*}\] Throughout, consider fixed value \(\delta = 1\) hours.

title: Hypoglycemia
text: defining prediction problem key parameters, provide code can used generate data ready AI prediction models. .parquet files generated code can used training testing.
code: srcs <- c("mimic_demo", "eicu_demo")  phys <- c(   "alt", "alp", "ast", "basos", "bicar", "bili", "ca", "cai", "tco2", "cl",   "crea", "dbp", "eos", "fio2", "hr", "hct", "hgb", "inr_pt", "lact", "lymph",   "mg", "mch", "mchc", "mcv", "map", "neut", "o2sat", "pco2", "po2", "ph",   "phos", "plt", "k", "pt", "ptt", "rdw", "rbc", "resp", "na", "sbp", "bun",   "wbc", "temp", "alb", "ck", "etco2", "crp", "gcs", "pafi", "safi",   "map_beta50", "map_beta100", "map_beta200", "be", "bili_dir", "bnd", "ckmb",   "esr", "fgn", "glu", "bmi", "age" )  meds <- c("tpn", "enteral", "cortico", "mech_vent", "dex_amount", "ins_ifx")  dat <- load_concepts(c(phys, meds), srcs, verbose = FALSE)  # carry-forward for physiological values dat <- fill_gaps(dat) dat <- replace_na(dat, type = "locf", vars = phys)  # 0-imputation for insulin values dat <- replace_na(dat, 0, vars = meds)  # determine the time of onset dat <- dat[, hypo := glu < 70]  # keep data only upto first hypo event dat <- dat[, past_hypo := cummax(hypo), by = c(id_vars(dat))] dat <- dat[, past_hypo := shift(past_hypo), by = c(id_vars(dat))] dat <- dat[past_hypo == 0 | is.na(past_hypo)] dat <- dat[, past_hypo := NULL]  # carry-backward the hypo label for 12 hours dat <- dat[, hypo := -hypo] dat <- slide(dat, hypo_lab := max(abs(hypo)), before = hours(0L),              after = hours(12L)) dat <- replace_na(dat, 0, vars = "hypo_lab")

title: Sepsis-3
text: Sepsis life-threatening reaction infection causes damage different tissues organs body. remains major public health issue associated high mortality, morbidity, related health costs [1–4]. current clinical gold standard identifying sepsis -called Sepsis-3 consensus, highlighted central role organ dysfunction definition, identification, prognostication, pathophysiological understanding sepsis [5]. sepsis onset, delay effective antimicrobial therapy, significantly increases mortality [ferrer2014, pruinelli2018, seymour2017]. Furthermore, sepsis complex heterogeneous syndrome, potentially reversible early stages, yet difficult identify, advanced stages become easier recognize, also challenging successfully treat [7]. Unfortunately, identifying bacterial species blood samples can take 48 hours [8], causing significant potentially detrimental delays confirming suspected infection. Meanwhile, abundance clinical laboratory data routinely collected, richest set accumulated intensive care unit (ICU). become harder intensivists manually process increasing quantities patient information [9], machine learning (ML) systems potential leverage data order provide alarm systems can aid clinician recognizing sepsis early stages, can possibly lead earlier treatment better patient outcomes ICU.

title: Sepsis-3
text: According sepsis-3 consensus, sepsis defined co-occurrence following two: suspected infection (defined antibiotic treatment body fluid sampling within specified time window), acute increase SOFA [10] score measures degree organ dysfunction. graphical representation sepsis-3 onset might occur ICU. particular, figure indicates, suspected infection (SI, short), defined : antibiotic administration (labeled ABX) time \(t_{abx}\) followed body fluid sampling (Sampling, time \(t_{samp}\)) within 24 hour window body fluid sampling followed antibiotic administration within 72 hour window earlier two times taken time suspected infection. , 72 hour window spanned around SI time (48 hours prior, 24 hours ). Within SI window, level SOFA score monitored, increase 2 points defines onset sepsis, time labeled \(t_{sep3}\) (earliest time taken, exists, subsequent increases ignored).

what: Sepsis-3 is not a stopping time
title: Sepsis-3
text: onset sepsis-3 stopping time [11]. , time sepsis-3 onset occurs, necessarily possible verify onset occurred (example, consider SOFA increase 2 points 0 hours, followed body fluid sampling 24 hours, antibiotic treatment 48 hours; case, sepsis-3 event occurring 0 hours confirmed 48 hours later). following parameters especially relevant prediction problem: \[\begin{align*}   L &= \text{early prior onset prediction valid} \\   R &= \text{much advance prediction valid} \\ \end{align*}\] consider choices \(L = 24\) hours \(R = t_{confirm} := \max\Big(t_{samp}, t_{abx}, t_{sep3}\Big)\) appropriate. words, alarm considered timely happens earlier 24 hours sepsis-3 onset. Furthermore, alarm considered informative happens later time sepsis-3 can definitively confirmed. Finally, designing alarm system, prevent alarm fatigue, alarms ring frequently, consider using alarm silencing, defined parameter: \[\begin{align*}     \delta = \text{duration alarm silencing alarm raised} \end{align*}\] sepsis-3, consider fixed value \(\delta = \infty\) hours, meaning alarm system silenced indefinitely raised first time.

title: Sepsis-3
text: two major data limitations trying compute sepsis-3 labels publicly available datasets considered repository. particular, highlight : eICU dataset reports body fluid sampling information small fraction patients, HiRID dataset reports body fluid sampling information. reason, alternative definition needs used datasets. alternative definition requires two antibiotic administrations within 24-hour window.

title: Sepsis-3
text: defining prediction problem key parameters, provide code can used generate data ready AI prediction models. .parquet files generated code can used training testing.
code: srcs <- c("mimic_demo", "eicu_demo")  phys <- c(   "alt", "alp", "ast", "basos", "bicar", "bili", "ca", "cai", "tco2", "cl",   "crea", "dbp", "eos", "fio2", "hr", "hct", "hgb", "inr_pt", "lact", "lymph",   "mg", "mch", "mchc", "mcv", "map", "neut", "o2sat", "pco2", "po2", "ph",   "phos", "plt", "k", "pt", "ptt", "rdw", "rbc", "resp", "na", "sbp", "bun",   "wbc", "temp", "alb", "ck", "etco2", "crp", "gcs", "pafi", "safi",   "map_beta50", "map_beta100", "map_beta200", "be", "bili_dir", "bnd", "ckmb",   "esr", "fgn", "glu", "bmi", "age" )  meds <- c("cortico", "mech_vent", "dex_amount", "ins_ifx")  dat <- load_concepts(c(phys, meds), srcs, verbose = FALSE)  # carry-forward for physiological variable dat <- fill_gaps(dat) dat <- replace_na(dat, type = "locf", vars = phys)  # 0-imputation for treatment variables dat <- replace_na(dat, 0, vars = meds)  # obtain onset information sep3 <- sep3_info(srcs) dat <- merge(dat, sep3, all.x = TRUE)  # remove times after t_confirm dat <- dat[, t_confirm := max_or_na(t_confirm), by = c(id_vars(dat))] dat <- dat[is.na(t_confirm), t_confirm := hours(Inf)] dat <- dat[get(index_var(dat)) <= t_confirm]  # carry-backward the sepsis-3 label for L = 24 hours dat <- slide(dat, sep3_lab := max_or_na(sep3), before = hours(0L),              after = hours(24L))  # carry-forward the sepsis-3 label until t_confirm dat <- dat[is.na(sep3_lab), sep3_lab := 0] dat <- dat[, sep3_lab := cummax(sep3_lab), by = c(id_vars(dat))]  # remove extra columns & times before ICU dat <- dat[, c("sep3", "t_confirm") := NULL] dat <- dat[get(index_var(dat)) >= hours(0L)]
